channel.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">REREV Automotive Glossary RSS
channel.description: Automotive terms and definitions from REREV.

image.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">REREV Automotive Glossary

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Differential definition and meaning
item.description: • A differential is a mechanical device that helps to distribute power from the engine to the wheels • It allows each wheel to rotate at different speeds, which is essential when turning corners • The differential consists of several gears and other components, and it usually sits between the drive shaft and the wheels

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">CVT definition and meaning
item.description: • A CVT is a type of automatic transmission that uses a pulley and belt system to provide an infinite number of gear ratios • This means that the engine can always operate at its optimal RPM level, resulting in improved fuel economy • CVTs are often found in smaller vehicles such as subcompacts and hybrids, but they are gradually becoming more common in mainstream cars as well

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Water pump definition and meaning
item.description: • A water pump in a car helps to circulate the coolant throughout the engine and prevent it from overheating • The water pump is driven by a belt that is connected to the crankshaft of the engine • As the engine runs, the water pump also turns and circulates the coolant

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Disc brakes definition and meaning
item.description: • Disc brakes are a type of braking system that uses calipers to press brake pads against a spinning disc, or rotor, to create friction and slow the vehicle • Disc brakes are found on all modern vehicles and are more effective than older drum brakes • There are two main types of disc brakes: mechanical and hydraulic

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Direct injection system definition and meaning
item.description: • The direct injection system is a fuel delivery system that injects fuel directly into the engine’s cylinders, rather than into the intake manifold • This system is often used in high-performance engines because it allows for more precise control of the fuel mixture and can result in improved engine performance • Direct injection systems can be either port injection or throttle body injection

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Rear defroster definition and meaning
item.description: • Rear defrosters are a common feature in many modern cars • They help to clear the rear window of frost, ice, or condensation, making it easier and safer to see out the back of the car • In some cases, rear defrosters may also be used to help melt snow or ice that has accumulated on the rear window or on other parts of the car

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Rim flange definition and meaning
item.description: • A rim flange is the part of a wheel that extends beyond the edge of the tire • Its purpose is to provide a place for the tire to sit on the wheel and protect it from damage • The width of the flange will vary depending on the width of the tire being used

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Cadillac definition and meaning
item.description: • Cadillac is an iconic American luxury car brand that has been around for over a century • Cadillac’s are known for their stylish designs, luxurious features, and powerful engines • Today, Cadillac offers a wide range of vehicles to suit any need or budget, from sedans and SUVs to sports cars and luxury vehicles

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Combined fuel economy definition and meaning
item.description: • Combined fuel economy is the average of a vehicle’s city fuel economy and highway fuel economy • City and highway fuel economies can be found on the Fuel Economy Guide, available at fueleconomy.gov • The guide provides estimates for all passenger cars and light-duty trucks model year 1984 and newer sold in the United States

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Service tire monitor system definition and meaning
item.description: • A service tire monitor system is a feature found on some vehicles that use sensors to keep track of the air pressure in each tire • If the pressure in one or more tires drops below a certain level, the system will warn the driver so that they can take action to avoid a possible blowout • Service tire monitor systems can help improve safety on the road, and they can also help extend the life of your tires by preventing them from being driven while they are underinflated

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Hydroplaning definition and meaning
item.description: • Hydroplaning is a dangerous condition that can occur when a vehicle’s tires lose contact with the road surface • This can happen when the road is wet or icy and can cause the car to spin out of control • Hydroplaning can be deadly, so it’s essential to know how to avoid it

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Dashboard definition and meaning
item.description: • Most cars on the road today have some form of dashboard, which is a display that provides the driver with information about the vehicle’s speed, fuel level, and other important data • While dashboards vary in design and functionality, they all serve the same purpose: to help the driver keep track of the car’s vital statistics • The first dashboards were introduced in the late 19th century, and they have come a long way since then

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Alignment definition and meaning
item.description: • A tire alignment is a service performed by a mechanic to ensure that your vehicle’s tires are properly aligned • This helps to improve gas mileage, handling, and tire wear • There are three different types of tire alignments: caster, camber, and toe

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Exhaust manifold definition and meaning
item.description: • The exhaust manifold is a crucial part of the car’s exhaust system • It is responsible for collecting the exhaust gases from the cylinders and directing them into the catalytic converter • The exhaust manifold also plays an important role in the car’s performance, as it can affect the engine’s ability to breathe

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Aftermarket accessory definition and meaning
item.description: • An aftermarket accessory is optional extra equipment that can be added to a car • These can include things like alloy wheels, body kits, and spoilers • They are usually fitted by specialist companies or garages and can often improve the look of a car

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Emission standards definition and meaning
item.description: • Emission standards are a set of regulations that limit the amount of pollutants that can be released into the atmosphere • These standards vary from country to country, but typically involve setting maximum limits for certain pollutants, such as carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and hydrocarbons • In cars, emission standards are typically accomplished through the use of catalytic converters

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">MAF sensor definition and meaning
item.description: • The MAF sensor is a key component in any car’s engine management system • It stands for “mass air flow” and is responsible for measuring the amount of air flowing into the engine • This information is then used by the engine control unit (ECU) to adjust the fuel injection and ignition timing accordingly

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire tread definition and meaning
item.description: • A tire’s tread is the part of the tire that comes into contact with the road • The tread is what provides traction, and it also helps to protect the rest of the tire from wear and tear • There are various tread patterns that can be used on tires, and each has its own advantages and disadvantages

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Automatic transmission definition and meaning
item.description: • Automatic transmission is a type of gearbox that uses a computer to control the gear selection • The main benefit of an automatic transmission is that it takes the guesswork out of shifting gears, which can be helpful when driving in stop-and-go traffic or in other challenging situations • There are several different types of automatic transmissions, each with its own advantages and disadvantages

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Optional equipment definition and meaning
item.description: • The term “optional equipment” encompasses a wide range of features that can be added to a car • Some optional equipment is standard on certain models or trim levels, while other features must be purchased as add-ons • Optional equipment can include anything from upgraded wheels and tires to more advanced safety features and infotainment systems

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">ATTS definition and meaning
item.description: • The Automatic Torque Transfer System (ATTS) is a technology that allows for the seamless transfer of torque between the front and rear axles of a vehicle • This system is designed to improve traction and stability, particularly in off-road or slippery conditions • The automatic torque transfer system can be found on a variety of vehicles, including many SUVs and trucks

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tesla definition and meaning
item.description: • Tesla is an electrical engineering and vehicle manufacturing company that was founded in 2003 • Tesla’s main products are electric cars, lithium-ion battery energy storage, solar panels, and home energy systems • Tesla Motors was founded in 2003 by a group of engineers who wanted to prove that electric cars could be better than gasoline-powered cars

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Crown definition and meaning
item.description: • The crown of a tire is the portion of the tire that comes into contact with the road • The shape of the crown determines how a tire will perform in different driving conditions • For example, a tire with a more rounded crown will provide better grip on wet or icy roads, while a tire with a flatter crown will provide better grip on dry roads

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Camber definition and meaning
item.description: • When a tire is mounted on a vehicle, the camber angle is the angle between the vertical axis of the wheel and the plane perpendicular to the ground • If the top of the wheel is closer to the vehicle than the bottom, then the camber angle is negative • If the bottom of the wheel is closer to the vehicle than the top, then the camber angle is positive

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Anti-theft alarm definition and meaning
item.description: • An anti-theft alarm in cars is a device that helps to prevent your car from being stolen • It works by making a loud noise when someone tries to break into your car, which will hopefully deter the thief and make them go away • There are many different types of anti-theft alarms available on the market, so it is vital to do some research to find the one that best suits your needs

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Timing belt definition and meaning
item.description: • A timing belt is a vital component in any car engine, and it is responsible for synchronizing the rotation of the crankshaft and camshaft • This ensures that the engine’s valves open and close at the correct time, allowing the engine to operate smoothly • The timing belt is located inside the engine and is usually made of rubber with metal or Kevlar reinforcement Over time, however, the timing belt can become stretched or damaged, which can cause the engine to misfire or even fail completely

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Bumper definition and meaning
item.description: • A bumper is a horizontal bar located at the front or rear of a vehicle • Its purpose is to absorb impact in a collision, minimizing damage to the vehicle’s bodywork • Bumpers are typically made of steel, aluminum, plastic, or fiberglass

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">HEMI definition and meaning
item.description: • HEMI engines are a type of internal combustion engine that gets its name from the semi-hemispherical shape of their combustion chamber • This design helps to create more power and torque than traditional engines, making HEMI engines a popular choice for high-performance vehicles • HEMI engines were first used in Chrysler cars in the 1950s, and they continue to be used in a variety of models today

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire oxidation definition and meaning
item.description: • Tire oxidation is the process by which oxygen breaks down the rubber in tires • This can happen due to sunlight, heat, or other environmental factors • Over time, this can cause the tire to become brittle and cracked

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Jeep definition and meaning
item.description: • Jeep is a brand of American automobiles owned by Stellantis • Jeep had been a part of Chrysler since 1987, when Chrysler acquired the Jeep brand, along with remaining assets, from its previous owner: American Motors Corporation (AMC) • The company was founded in 1941 as Willys-Overland Motors, an American automobile manufacturer that produced Jeeps for the Allied forces during World War II

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">AT-PZEV definition and meaning
item.description: • AT-PZEV is an acronym for Advanced Technology Partial Zero Emission Vehicle • As its name suggests, AT-PZEV vehicles are designed to emit significantly fewer pollutants than traditional gasoline-powered cars and trucks • One of the key ways AT-PZEV vehicles reduce emissions is by using a technology called catalytic reduction

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Awareness aids definition and meaning
item.description: • Awareness aids in cars are designed to help drivers be more aware of their surroundings • These aids can include features like blind spot monitoring, rear-view cameras, and lane departure warning systems • By helping drivers to be more aware of their surroundings, these aids can help to reduce the number of accidents on the road

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Adaptive headlights definition and meaning
item.description: • Adaptive headlights are a type of automotive headlight that adjusts the beam pattern in response to the vehicle’s speed and steering angle • This allows for better illumination of the road ahead, particularly when cornering • There are two main types of adaptive headlights: those that use a motorized reflector, and those that use an array of LEDs

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Headlights definition and meaning
item.description: • Headlights are a car’s main source of light, used to illuminate the road ahead during nighttime and low-visibility conditions • Headlights are typically made up of a housing that contains the light source (usually a halogen or LED bulb), a reflector to direct the light, and a lens to protect the bulb and reflector • Many newer cars also feature projector headlights, which use a shaped reflector to create a more focused beam of light

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Acquisition fee definition and meaning
item.description: • An acquisition fee is a one-time charge assessed by a financial institution when you purchase a vehicle • This fee is generally rolled into your loan, so you’ll pay interest on it over the life of the loan • The acquisition fee can vary depending on the lender If you’re financing your vehicle through a dealership, they may try adding an “acquisition fee” as part of the total loan amount

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire sidewall definition and meaning
item.description: • A tire sidewall is the portion of the tire that extends from the tread to the bead • It is typically made from rubber and reinforced with fabric or steel cords • The sidewall plays an important role in supporting the weight of the vehicle and helps protect the tire from punctures and other damage

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air pump filter definition and meaning
item.description: • An air pump filter is a device that helps remove impurities from the air being pumped into a car’s engine • The filter is usually located between the air pump and the carburetor or fuel injection system • It is important to keep the air pump filter clean so that it can continue to do its job properly

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">General Motors definition and meaning
item.description: • General Motors, or GM, is an American multinational corporation headquartered in Detroit, Michigan • Founded in 1908 as a holding company for Buick, Cadillac, and Oldsmobile, GM soon became the largest automaker in the world • Today, GM produces cars and trucks under eight brands: Buick, Cadillac, Chevrolet, GMC, Holden, Opel, Vauxhall, and Wuling

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Balance shaft definition and meaning
item.description: • A balance shaft is a shaft that helps to cancel out the vibrations caused by the engine’s pistons • It is usually located between the cylinder banks in the engine’s crankshaft • The balance shaft rotates at the same speed as the crankshaft but in the opposite direction

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Kia definition and meaning
item.description: • Kia is a car company based in South Korea • It is the second largest automobile manufacturer in the country, behind only Hyundai • Kia has been producing cars since 1944, and today offers a wide range of vehicles, from sedans and SUVs to vans and trucks

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air filter restriction indicator definition and meaning
item.description: • An air filter restriction indicator is a device that measures the amount of airflow restrictions in an air filter • It is used to help determine when the air filter needs to be replaced • The indicator typically consists of a small, hand-held sensor that is placed inside the air filter housing

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Suzuki definition and meaning
item.description: • Suzuki is a Japanese automaker that produces cars, motorcycles, ATVs, and outboard motors • Suzuki has been in operation since 1909 and has its headquarters in Hamamatsu, Japan • The company also has manufacturing facilities in many other countries around the world, including the United States, India, Pakistan, Hungary, and Indonesia

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire groove definition and meaning
item.description: • A tire groove is a narrow channel or rib that runs around the circumference of a tire • These grooves are essential to the proper function of the tire, as they help to evacuate water and other debris from beneath the tread surface • Tire grooves also provide biting edges that allow the tire grip the road surface in wet or icy conditions

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Adjustable suspension definition and meaning
item.description: • Adjustable suspension is a type of vehicle suspension that allows the driver to adjust the ride height and firmness of the suspension • This can be done by adjusting the spring rate, damping, and/or ride height • The adjustable suspension provides passengers a more comfortable ride and improved driver handling

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Braking assist definition and meaning
item.description: • When you press the brake pedal, your car’s braking assist system kicks in to help stop the vehicle • This system uses sensors to detect how hard you are pressing the pedal and then applies extra force to the brakes if needed • This can help you stop more quickly and safely in an emergency situation

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Polymer definition and meaning
item.description: • Polymers are materials made up of long chains of molecules • They have a wide range of properties, making them useful in a variety of applications • One common use for polymers is in cars

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">City fuel economy definition and meaning
item.description: • City fuel economy is the average number of miles per gallon that a vehicle gets in urban driving conditions • Fuel economy can vary greatly depending on a number of factors, such as the type of vehicle, the size of the engine, and the way the car is driven • Fuel economy is important to consider when choosing a car, as it can have a significant impact on your monthly fuel costs

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">C-pillar definition and meaning
item.description: • The C-pillar is the structural support between the rear door and the back window of a vehicle • In a unibody construction, it is typically made from sheet metal • The C-pillar provides strength and stiffness to the vehicle body, and also helps to protect passengers in the event of a rear impact collision

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brake fluid definition and meaning
item.description: • Brake fluid is a hydraulic fluid used in brake systems • It transfers force from the pedal to the brakes, and also provides a way for the heat generated by braking to be dissipated • Over time, brake fluid can become contaminated and lose effectiveness, so it needs to be replaced periodically

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Overdrive definition and meaning
item.description: • Overdrive is a feature in many modern cars that allows the engine to run at a lower rpm for a given road speed • This can improve fuel economy and reduce engine noise • Overdrive is typically engaged by selecting a higher gear ratio on the transmission, such as fourth gear instead of third

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Catalytic converter definition and meaning
item.description: • The catalytic converter in a car is responsible for cleaning up exhaust fumes before they are released into the atmosphere • Catalytic converters contain a catalyst, which is a substance that helps to speed up chemical reactions • In this case, the catalyst helps to convert harmful pollutants in exhaust fumes into less harmful substances

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Accelerator pedal linkage definition and meaning
item.description: • Accelerator pedal linkage is the system that connects the accelerator pedal to the throttle body or carburetor • This system allows the driver to control the amount of air and fuel entering the engine and, therefore, how much power the engine produces • The accelerator pedal linkage can be made up of various parts, depending on the vehicle

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Boost pressure definition and meaning
item.description: • Boost pressure is the extra pressure generated by a turbocharger or supercharger in an engine • More air is being forced into the engine, leading to increased power • Boost pressure is often measured in bar or PSI (Pounds per Square Inch)

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Speed sensor definition and meaning
item.description: • A speed sensor is a device used to measure the speed of a car • It is typically mounted on the front or rear bumper, and consists of a sensor and an antenna • The sensor measures the speed of the car by sending out pulses of electromagnetic waves, and the antenna receives these waves and calculates the car’s speed

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Anti-roll bar definition and meaning
item.description: • An anti-roll bar is a device that helps resist a vehicle’s rolling • It is usually located between the wheels and consists of a bar connected to the suspension on each side • The purpose of an anti-roll bar is to keep the body of the vehicle level when cornering by providing resistance to the rolling force exerted by the vehicle’s weight

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Parking sensors definition and meaning
item.description: • Parking sensors are devices that emit sound waves in order to detect objects behind a vehicle • These devices can be very useful in helping to avoid accidents, especially when backing up • Parking sensors are usually installed near the bumper of a car, and they work by emitting sound waves that bounce off of objects and then return to the sensor

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Volvo definition and meaning
item.description: • Volvo Cars is a Swedish luxury vehicle manufacturer founded in 1927 and headquartered on Hisingen in Gothenburg • Since 2010 it has been owned by the Chinese multinational Geely Holding Group • The company manufactures and markets sport utility vehicles (SUVs), station wagons, sedans, and compact executive sedans

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Stability control system definition and meaning
item.description: • A stability control system is a computerized system that helps a driver maintain control of his or her vehicle • It does this by constantly monitoring the speed and direction of the car, and comparing it to the driver’s input • If the car starts to veer off course, the system will automatically apply the brakes to one or more wheels, and may also reduce engine power

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Crumple zone definition and meaning
item.description: • Crumple zone is a safety feature in modern cars that is designed to protect occupants in the event of a collision • The crumple zone is typically located at the front of the vehicle, and it works by absorbing the impact of a collision and spreading the force over a larger area • This reduces the chances of serious injury or death for occupants of the car

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Ford definition and meaning
item.description: • Ford is an American multinational automaker headquartered in Dearborn, Michigan, a suburb of Detroit • The company was founded by Henry Ford and incorporated on June 16, 1903 • The company sells automobiles and commercial vehicles under the Ford brand and most luxury cars under the Lincoln brand

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Plus size wheels definition and meaning
item.description: • Plus size wheels are larger than standard wheels and provide a variety of benefits for both drivers and their vehicles • Plus size wheels can improve the look of a vehicle, give it better handling characteristics, and make it easier to find replacement tires • In addition, plus size wheels can help to protect against flats and other tire damage

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tie rod definition and meaning
item.description: • A tie rod is a component of a car’s suspension system that helps to link the wheel hubs to the steering mechanism • The tie rod is usually made of metal and consists of two parts: an inner rod and an outer sleeve • The inner rod is connected to the wheel hub, while the outer sleeve is connected to the steering mechanism

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brake lining definition and meaning
item.description: • Brake lining is a type of material used in brakes that helps to create friction and stopping power • It is typically made from a variety of materials such as asbestos, metal, or ceramic • Brake lining is an important part of the braking system and helps to ensure safe stopping

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire air pressure definition and meaning
item.description: • Tire air pressure is the amount of air that is in each tire on your vehicle • The proper tire air pressure for your car is usually listed on a sticker inside the driver’s door • If not, you can usually find it in your car’s owner’s manual

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">A-pillar definition and meaning
item.description: • An A-pillar is the vertical support structure on either side of a vehicle’s windshield • In many cars, the a-pillars are located at the extreme front corners of the windshield opening • The A-pillars provide critical support for the roof and help to protect occupants in a rollover accident by preventing the roof from collapsing

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">ACV definition and meaning
item.description: • The actual cash value (ACV) of a car is its fair market value as determined by an appraiser • The ACV takes into account the vehicle’s age, condition, mileage, and any optional equipment or features that may add to its resale value • When an insurance company pays out a claim for a totaled car, the check is typically made out to the policyholder for the ACV of the vehicle

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">AdBlue definition and meaning
item.description: • AdBlue is a trademarked name for a urea-based solution used in selective catalytic reduction (SCR) to reduce NOx emissions from diesel engines • SCR is a means of converting nitrogen oxides (NOx), which are harmful pollutants, into harmless nitrogen and water vapor • Diesel engines are responsible for a large percentage of NOx emissions, so using AdBlue can significantly reduce these emissions

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air conditioner refrigerant definition and meaning
item.description: • An air conditioner refrigerant is a substance used in AC units to help cool the air • The refrigerant evaporates at a low temperature and condenses at a high temperature, drawing heat out of the air as it does so • This process helps to keep your home or office cool and comfortable

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Automated manual transmission definition and meaning
item.description: • Automated manual transmission, also known as AMT, is a type of gearbox that combines features of both automatic and manual transmissions • AMT gearboxes are increasingly becoming popular in cars, especially in India where they offer a more affordable alternative to traditional automatic transmissions • AMT gearboxes work by using an electronic control unit (ECU) to automatically actuate the clutch and shift gears, without the need for the driver to use a clutch pedal or shifter

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Heated windshield definition and meaning
item.description: • Heated windshields in cars are a great feature that helps to improve visibility and comfort while driving • The heated element in the windshield helps to melting ice and snow, making it easier to see through the windshield • In addition, the heat can also help to prevent fogging on the inside of the windshield

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">A/C compressor definition and meaning
item.description: • The A/C compressor is a vital component of your air conditioning system • It is responsible for circulating refrigerant throughout the system, and its job is to pressurize the refrigerant so that it can evaporate and cool the air in your car • without the compressor, your A/C system would not be able to function

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Overheating definition and meaning
item.description: • Overheating can occur in any type of car, but it is most common in older vehicles • There are many reasons why a car might overheat, but the most common cause is a problem with the cooling system • The cooling system is responsible for keeping the engine at a safe temperature, so if there is a problem with this system, it can cause the engine to overheat

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Toyota definition and meaning
item.description: • Toyota is one of the world’s largest automobile manufacturers and a leading global corporation • Founded in 1937, Toyota now sells vehicles in 170 countries and employs over 300,000 people • A household name in the automotive industry, Toyota is best known for its line of reliable and affordable cars and trucks

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Anti-locking brake system definition and meaning
item.description: • The anti-locking brake system (ABS) is a safety feature that helps prevent the wheels from locking up during sudden braking or skidding • This prevents the vehicle from losing control and allows the driver to maintain control • ABS is an important safety feature that can help avoid accidents, but it is crucial to understand how it works and when to use it

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Carbon dioxide definition and meaning
item.description: • Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a gas that is produced when burning fossil fuels such as petrol and diesel • It is also released when organic matter decomposes • CO2 is present in the Earth’s atmosphere and is one of the greenhouse gases that trap heat and contribute to global warming

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Climate-controlled seats definition and meaning
item.description: • Climate-controlled seats are a feature found in some newer cars that helps to keep passengers comfortable in extreme weather conditions • The seats are equipped with sensors that monitor the temperature and humidity levels in the car, and adjust the seat heating and cooling accordingly • This can be a great feature for those who live in areas with very hot or cold climates, as it helps to keep everyone in the car comfortable no matter what the weather is like outside

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Chassis definition and meaning
item.description: • Chassis is the term used to describe the frame and body of a vehicle • It is the foundation upon which all other components are built, and provides both strength and rigidity to the car • A well-designed chassis is essential for any vehicle, as it ensures safety and stability on the road

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Bolstering definition and meaning
item.description: • Bolstering is a term used to describe a car’s structure’s support to the occupants • It includes the seats, seatbelts, and airbags • The purpose of bolstering is to keep the occupants in place during a crash so that they are less likely to be injured

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Engine oil definition and meaning
item.description: • Engine oil is a key component of your car’s engine • It lubricates the moving parts of your engine, and helps to keep it cool • Over time, engine oil breaks down and needs to be replaced

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">What is a blind spot? definition and meaning
item.description: • A blind spot is an area around the vehicle that cannot be seen by the driver, either through the windshield or in the mirrors • Blind spots can be dangerous because they can make it difficult for drivers to see other vehicles, pedestrians, or obstacles, which can lead to accidents • There are three main ways to avoid blind spots: by using your mirrors properly, by using your turn signals, and by being aware of your surroundings

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Fog lights definition and meaning
item.description: • Fog lights are a type of auxiliary light that is installed on the front of a vehicle • Fog lights help to improve visibility during periods of poor weather, such as fog, rain, or snow • When used correctly, fog lights can help to prevent accidents by making it easier for drivers to see the road ahead

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Antenna definition and meaning
item.description: • The antenna is a device that helps to transmit and receive radio waves • In cars, the antenna is usually located on the roof or in the front grille • It is used to receive signals from radio towers and to send signals to other vehicles

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brake pedal definition and meaning
item.description: • A brake pedal is a pedal in a vehicle that is pushed down in order to engage the brakes • The purpose of the brake pedal is to stop the vehicle from moving forward • When the brake pedal is depressed, it activates a hydraulic system that applies pressure to the brakes, causing them to slow down or stop

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Limited warranty definition and meaning
item.description: • Most carmakers offer a limited warranty on their vehicles • This means that if something goes wrong with your car, the manufacturer will cover the cost of repairs up to a certain amount • The length of time that a limited warranty lasts varies from one manufacturer to another, but it is typically between three and five years

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Ethanol definition and meaning
item.description: • Ethanol is an organic compound with the chemical formula C2H6O • It is a colorless, flammable liquid with a strong odor • It is commonly used as a fuel, solvent, and antiseptic

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brake booster definition and meaning
item.description: • A brake booster is a device that helps to increase the pressure in a vehicle’s braking system • It is usually located between the master cylinder and the brakes themselves and uses vacuum pressure to help build up the necessary force to stop the vehicle • Brake boosters can be either electrically or mechanically operated, though most modern vehicles use an electrical pump to provide the extra pressure

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Certified pre-owned vehicle definition and meaning
item.description: • Certified pre-owned (CPO) vehicles are late-model used cars that have been inspected, refurbished and certified by a manufacturer or other authority • CPO cars come with extended warranties and other benefits that make them a good choice for used-car shoppers • Certified pre-owned cars are popular because they offer many of the same benefits as new cars at a lower price

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Steering rack definition and meaning
item.description: • The steering rack is a key component in the steering system of a car • It is what helps to convert the turning force of the steering wheel into the necessary force to turn the wheels of the car • The steering rack is usually located between the front wheels of the car, and consists of a series of bars that are connected to the steering wheel on one end, and to the suspension on the other

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">CV joint noise when driving straight — cause and fixes
item.description: • Years of driving often leave a mark on the vehicle’s drivetrain and suspension, and this could cause driving noises • In case of a CV joint noise, you might experience some crunching and clicking while turning slowly • However, you might be a bit confused if you encounter CV joint noise when driving straight

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Fuel tank definition and meaning
item.description: • A fuel tank is a safe container for storing flammable liquids • A typical fuel tank holds anywhere from 10 to 20 gallons of gasoline • The size and capacity of the fuel tank varies depending on the make and model of the vehicle

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Driveshaft definition and meaning
item.description: • A driveshaft is a mechanical component that couples two other components, typically rotational, in order to transmit power from one to the other • In many cases, one of the components is driven by an engine or motor, while the other component provides resistance to this force, resulting in torque being transferred between the two • Driveshafts are commonly used in automotive applications, where they serve to connect the engine and transmission

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Subaru definition and meaning
item.description: • Subaru is a Japanese car manufacturer that is part of the Subaru Corporation, previously known as the Fuji Heavy Industries group • The company produces a wide range of vehicles, including sedans, wagons, crossovers, and SUVs • Subaru’s most well-known model is the Impreza, which has been produced since 1992

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Beam axle definition and meaning
item.description: • A beam axle is a type of automobile suspension system that uses a single beam or shaft to connect the left and right wheels • This construction is typical of older vehicles, as well as some off-road and heavy-duty vehicles • The main advantage of a beam axle is its simplicity and low manufacturing cost

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">PSI definition and meaning
item.description: • PSI stands for “Pounds per Square Inch.” PSI is a measurement unit expressing the amount of force exerted on a given area • For example, if you were to put a 1-pound weight on a 1-square-inch area, the pressure would be 1 PSI • In the context of tires, PSI measures how much air pressure is inside the tire

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Crash test ratings definition and meaning
item.description: • Crash test ratings are used to evaluate the safety of a car in the event of a crash • These ratings are based on tests conducted by various organizations, such as the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) • The ratings take into account factors such as the strength of the car’s structure, its ability to protect occupants in a crash, and its likelihood of causing injuries to other motorists or pedestrians

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Carburetor definition and meaning
item.description: • A carburetor is a device that mixes air and fuel for internal combustion engines • It is typically located between the air filter and the intake manifold, and it delivers a mixture of air and fuel to the engine cylinders • The carburetor has a float-type bowl that holds a supply of fuel, and it uses a jet to draw fuel from the bowl and mix it with air

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">AWD definition and meaning
item.description: • All-wheel drive (AWD) is a vehicle drivetrain that allows all four wheels to simultaneously receive power from the engine • This can provide increased traction and stability, especially in slippery or off-road conditions • While AWD systems have been around for decades, they have become increasingly popular in recent years as more and more automakers offer them as an option on their vehicles

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">VIN definition and meaning
item.description: • A Vehicle Identification Number, or VIN, is a 17-digit code used to identify a specific car • The VIN can be found on the dash near the windshield, on the driver’s side door jamb, or on your car’s registration card • The VIN is composed of several sections:

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Chevrolet definition and meaning
item.description: • Chevrolet is an American car manufacturer that was founded in 1911 by Louis Chevrolet and William C • Durant • The company has been a subsidiary of General Motors (GM) since 1918

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Coupe definition and meaning
item.description: • A coupe is a closed car body style with two doors • Coupes typically have sleek, elongated roofs and may or may not have a rear seat • Typically, coupes are sportier and more stylish than sedans

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">DMV definition and meaning
item.description: • The Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) is responsible for issuing driver’s licenses, registering vehicles, and maintaining records • The DMV also plays a role in enforcing traffic laws and investigating accidents • In some states, the DMV is also responsible for issuing ID cards, registering boats, and handling other types of vehicles

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tail lights definition and meaning
item.description: • Tail lights are located at the rear of a vehicle and help other drivers see the car’s direction and braking • They usually have a red lens and may also contain reverse lights and turn signals • It is important to make sure that tail lights are clean and working properly so that other drivers can see the car’s direction, particularly when it is dark or foggy

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Cord angle definition and meaning
item.description: • The cord angle is the angle between the tire’s cords and the centerline of the tread • This angle affects the tire’s ability to flex and resist deformation under load • A higher cord angle provides greater resistance to deformation, while a lower cord angle allows for more flexibility

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Jumpstart definition and meaning
item.description: • Jump-starting a car is a process that involves using a battery from another vehicle or source to start your car’s engine • This can be done by connecting the positive and negative terminals of the batteries together, which will create a spark that will start the engine • You can also use a jump starter kit, which will have all of the necessary cables and supplies needed to jumpstart a car

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Contact patch definition and meaning
item.description: • A contact patch is the area of a tire that is in contact with the ground • The size of the contact patch can vary depending on the type of tire, but it is typically smaller than the rest of the tire • The contact patch is important because it affects the traction and handling of a vehicle

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Active pedestrian protection system definition and meaning
item.description: • An active pedestrian protection system is a vehicle safety feature that uses sensors to detect pedestrians and cyclists in the vehicle’s path and then takes steps to avoid or mitigate a collision • These systems can be found on both cars and trucks and are designed to protect not only the occupants of the vehicle but also pedestrians and cyclists outside of it • Active pedestrian protection systems are becoming increasingly common, as they are effective at preventing or mitigating collisions

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brush guard definition and meaning
item.description: • A brush guard is a type of car accessory that helps protect the front of your vehicle from scratches, dents, and other damage • It typically consists of a steel or aluminum frame that attaches to the bumper and extends up over the grill • Some brush guards also include side panels that wrap around the headlights

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Supercharger definition and meaning
item.description: • A supercharger is a device that compresses the air entering the engine, thereby increasing its power and efficiency • Superchargers are typically used in high-performance cars and motorcycles • A supercharger increases the amount of air that flows into the engine by compressing it

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Nissan definition and meaning
item.description: • Nissan is a Japanese automaker that produces cars, trucks and SUVs • Nissan’s global headquarters is located in Yokohama, Japan, and its North American headquarters is in Franklin, Tennessee • Nissan has been part of the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance since 1999

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Aerodynamic drag definition and meaning
item.description: • Aerodynamic drag is a force that acts on a car when it moves through the air • This force opposes the forward motion of the car and reduces its speed • The faster the car moves, the greater the aerodynamic drag

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Adaptive cruise control definition and meaning
item.description: • Adaptive cruise control is a feature found on newer vehicles • It uses sensors to monitor the distance between your car and the one in front of you and then automatically adjusts your speed to maintain a safe following distance • This can help relieve some of the stress of driving in stop-and-go traffic or on long road trips

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Clutch pedal definition and meaning
item.description: • The clutch pedal is a vital component of a manual transmission car • It is responsible for engaging and disengaging the engine from the transmission, which allows the driver to change gears • The pedal is usually located on the left side of the steering column

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Clutch definition and meaning
item.description: • A clutch is a device that helps transmission of energy from one component to another • In a car, the engine turns a shaft called the crankshaft • The crankshaft is connected to the wheels by a series of gears, and the clutch allows those gears to engage and disengage as needed

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Uniform tire quality grading (UTQG) definition and meaning
item.description: • The Uniform Tire Quality Grading (UTQG) system is a standard by the U.S • Department of Transportation that provides drivers with information about a tire’s ability to resist tread wear and traction in dry and wet conditions • The system uses a letter grading scale, with “A” being the highest grade and “C” being the lowest

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Volkswagen definition and meaning
item.description: • Volkswagen is a German car manufacturer that was founded in 1937 by the German Labour Front • The company’s name means “people’s car” in German • Volkswagen is the largest car manufacturer in Europe, and it also owns a number of other brands, including Audi, Bentley, Bugatti, Lamborghini, Porsche, and SEAT

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Design rim definition and meaning
item.description: • Design rims are an important factor to consider when shopping for tires • They can affect a tire’s performance and durability • It is important to choose the right design rim for your vehicle to get the most out of your tires

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Console definition and meaning
item.description: • Console is an important component in any car • It houses the car’s controls and instruments, and provides a central location for the driver to interact with the car • The console is typically located in the center of the car, between the front seats

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Bead definition and meaning
item.description: • Bead of the wheel or tire bead is a phrase used to describe the outermost edge of a wheel • This area is often raised and reinforced to provide additional strength and durability to the wheel • Beads of wheel can also help to improve the grip of a wheel on a surface, making it less likely to slip or skid

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Comprehensive insurance definition and meaning
item.description: • Comprehensive insurance is a type of car insurance that covers damage to your vehicle from events other than collisions • This includes damage from weather, fire, theft, and vandalism • Comprehensive insurance also covers any damage you may cause to another person’s property, such as their car

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Antifreeze definition and meaning
item.description: • Antifreeze is a substance used in vehicles and other machinery to keep them from freezing up in cold weather • It is typically made from ethylene glycol or propylene glycol and added to the water in the radiator to lower its freezing point • Antifreeze also raises the boiling point of the coolant, which helps to prevent engine overheating

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Adjustable pedals definition and meaning
item.description: • Adjustable pedals allow you to adjust the distance between the accelerator and brake pedal and the height of each pedal • Most newer cars come equipped with adjustable pedals, but if your car doesn’t have them, there are a number of aftermarket options available • There are many benefits to having adjustable pedals in your car

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Chrysler definition and meaning
item.description: • Chrysler is an American automobile manufacturer • Chrysler was founded in 1925 by Walter Chrysler • The company has been a subsidiary of Italian multinational automaker Fiat Chrysler Automobiles since 2014, and previously it was controlled by German automaker DaimlerChrysler from 1998 to 2007

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire sipe definition and meaning
item.description: • A tire sipe is a small groove or slit in a tire’s tread that helps improve traction, especially in wet or icy conditions • Sipes can also help reduce tread squirm and improve fuel economy • Most tires have some form of sipe, but they are more common on winter tires and all-season tires designed for use in colder climates.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Diesel engine definition and meaning
item.description: • The diesel engine is an internal combustion engine that uses compression to ignite the fuel, rather than using a spark plug like a gasoline engine • The diesel engine was invented by Rudolf Diesel in 1892 • These engines are more efficient than gasoline engines and produce less pollution

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire load definition and meaning
item.description: • A tire’s load rating measures how much weight the tire can support • The higher the load rating, the more weight the tire can support • Most passenger vehicles have tires with a load rating of 60 or higher

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">All-season tires definition and meaning
item.description: • All-season tires are designed to provide good traction and handling in various driving conditions, including wet and dry pavement and in light snow • They typically have deeper treads than summer tires and may also contain special compounds and tread patterns that help improve grip on slippery surfaces • Some all-season tires are even rated for severe snow service, which means they can be used year-round in areas where winter weather is a regular occurrence

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire permeation definition and meaning
item.description: • Tire permeation is the process by which tire-derived chemicals can enter the environment • These chemicals can come from various sources, including the production and use of tires, and can pose risks to human health and the environment • There are several ways in which tire-derived chemicals can enter the environment, including through:

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Rear seat entertainment system definition and meaning
item.description: • A rear seat entertainment system is a set of multimedia components installed in a vehicle’s backseat • These systems typically include a display screen, speakers, and inputs for various media sources • The purpose of a rear seat entertainment system is to keep passengers entertained during long trips

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">D-pillar definition and meaning
item.description: • The D-pillar is the vertical structural member at the back of a vehicle’s cabin, located between the rear side windows • It provides support for the rear window and reinforces the vehicle’s structure • In many cars, the D-pillar also houses the car’s rear wiper motor

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Flywheel definition and meaning
item.description: • A flywheel is a mechanical device that stores energy and keeps a vehicle’s engine running smoothly • It is usually made of heavy metal and is mounted on the front of the engine • The flywheel helps to keep the engine speed constant by storing energy from the combustion process and then releasing it as needed

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Cord definition and meaning
item.description: • Cord is the reinforcing material in a tire that gives it strength • It is made from steel, polyester, or nylon and is found in the body of the tire between the tread and the bead • The number of cords in a tire’s construction (known as “cord count”) affects the tire’s strength, durability, and puncture resistance

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Upholstery definition and meaning
item.description: • Upholstery is the material that covers the seats and other interior surfaces of a car • It can be made from a variety of materials, including cloth, leather, vinyl, or a synthetic mixture • Upholstery is typically used to protect the car’s interior surfaces from wear and tear, as well as to provide a comfortable surface for passengers to sit on

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Skid resistance definition and meaning
item.description: • Skid resistance measures the friction between a tire and the road surface • The higher the skid resistance, the more grip the tire has on the road • Skid resistance is important for both safety and performance

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Anti-dive definition and meaning
item.description: • Most modern cars are equipped with anti-dive suspension systems • This type of suspension is designed to prevent the nose of the car from “diving” down during braking • Anti-dive suspension systems use a variety of different methods to achieve this, but they all work to keep the car’s center of gravity more level during braking

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Leg room definition and meaning
item.description: • Leg room is the amount of space between the front and back seats in a vehicle • It is measured from the hip joint to the back of the seat • The average leg room in a car is about 42 inches

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Sedan definition and meaning
item.description: • A sedan is a car with four doors and typically seating five passengers • The term “sedan” comes from the French word for “room” or “chamber.” Sedans are typically mid-sized or larger cars, and they may have either front-wheel drive or rear-wheel drive • Many sedans also have a trunk, which is a separate storage area located at the back of the car

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air dam definition and meaning
item.description: • An air dam is a car part that helps improve a vehicle’s aerodynamics by redirecting airflow • It is located at the front of the car, below the bumper, and helps to reduce drag and improve fuel efficiency • Many newer cars have air dams as standard equipment, but they can also be added to older vehicles

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire accelerator definition and meaning
item.description: • A tire accelerator is a chemical that speeds up the vulcanization of rubber in tires • It’s used in tire compounds to shorten the curing time • Several different types are available, each with its own advantages and disadvantages

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Alternator definition and meaning
item.description: • An alternator is a device that produces alternating current (AC) • It is commonly used in cars to power the electrical system when the engine is running • The alternator charges the battery and powers the car’s electrical accessories such as the lights, radio, and air conditioning

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Climate control definition and meaning
item.description: • Climate control is a feature in many modern cars that allows the driver and passengers to regulate the temperature inside the vehicle • This can be done by either heating or cooling the air, depending on the weather conditions outside • Climate control is especially useful in extreme weather conditions, when the temperature inside a car can become uncomfortable very quickly

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire aspect ratio definition and meaning
item.description: • A tire’s aspect ratio is the ratio of its width to its height • In other words, it is the relationship between the tire’s width and the sidewall’s height • The aspect ratio is important because it affects several things, including the tire’s handling, ride comfort, and load-carrying capacity

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Mazda definition and meaning
item.description: • Mazda is a Japanese automaker that produces cars, trucks, SUVs, and crossovers • The company has been in operation since 1931 and has since become one of the most popular automakers in the world • Mazda is known for producing high-quality vehicles that offer excellent performance, fuel efficiency, and value

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Battery definition and meaning
item.description: • Electric battery is a device that uses chemical reactions to store and release electrical energy • It is the most common type of battery used in cars • Electric batteries are made up of one or more cells, each of which contains positive and negative electrodes separated by an electrolyte

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Rear spoiler definition and meaning
item.description: • A rear spoiler is an aerodynamic device that is typically installed on the back of a car • Its purpose is to improve the vehicle’s aerodynamic performance by reducing drag and providing additional downforce • Spoilers are most commonly found on sports cars, but they can also be installed on other types of vehicles

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">ETRTO definition and meaning
item.description: • ETRTO is the European Tire and Rim Technical Organization • They are responsible for setting standards for tire and rim dimensions across Europe • These standards help ensure that tires and rims fit properly together, and help to prevent problems like mismatched tires and rims

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Ball joint definition and meaning
item.description: • A ball joint is a mechanical part that connects two moving parts of a vehicle • It allows free movement in certain directions while still providing support and stability in other directions • Ball joints are essential for the suspension system of a vehicle and help to keep the wheels in contact with the ground

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Axle definition and meaning
item.description: • An axle is a shaft that connects two wheels • In a vehicle such as a car, the axle allows the wheels to rotate freely while supporting the car’s weight • The axle also transmits power from the engine to the wheels

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air conditioning filter definition and meaning
item.description: • An air conditioning filter is a filter that is placed in the air conditioner unit of a car • This filter helps remove impurities from the air circulated through the car’s air conditioner • Doing so helps improve the air quality inside the vehicle and makes it more comfortable for the occupants

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Airbag definition and meaning
item.description: • An airbag is a type of safety device that is installed in vehicles • It is designed to inflate in the event of a collision, providing a cushion for the vehicle’s occupants • Airbags have been shown to be effective in reducing injuries and fatalities in collisions

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Horsepower definition and meaning
item.description: • Horsepower is a unit of measurement that determines the power of an engine • The higher the horsepower, the more powerful the engine • Horsepower is important in determining the performance of a car

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Combustion chamber definition and meaning
item.description: • A combustion chamber is a space where the fuel-air mixture in an internal combustion engine is burnt • The hot gases produced by combustion are what provide the energy to power the engine • In most car engines, the cylinders are the combustion chambers

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Tire age definition and meaning
item.description: • As tires age, they can become more brittle and dry out • This can lead to cracks forming in the sidewalls or treads • Over time, these cracks can get larger and cause the tire to leak air or even blowout while in use

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Child seat definition and meaning
item.description: • A child seat is a seat designed specifically for children to sit in • Child seats are usually made from durable materials such as plastic or metal, and they often have a built-in harness or other safety features to keep kids safe while riding in them • Many child seats also have adjustable straps or other mechanisms to ensure a comfortable and secure fit for kids of all sizes

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Bushing definition and meaning
item.description: • Bushing is a term used to describe a type of connection between two parts of a car • It is typically a cylindrical piece of metal or plastic that fits over a shaft or rod, and is used to connect two moving parts • It is typically made from bronze or another metal and can be found in a variety of industries including automotive, manufacturing, and more

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">BMW definition and meaning
item.description: • BMW stands for Bayerische Motoren Werke AG, which translates to Bavarian Motor Works • This German company started out as an aircraft engine manufacturer in 1916 and has since become one of the most well-known and respected automakers in the world • BMW is known for producing high-quality, luxury vehicles that offer excellent performance and cutting-edge technology

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Parking assist definition and meaning
item.description: • Most new cars come with some form of parking assist, which can make parallel parking and maneuvering into tight spots much easier • Parking assist uses sensors to detect objects around the vehicle and then provide steering input to help guide the car into the desired spot • Some systems will even parallel park the car for you

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">A/C drain hose definition and meaning
item.description: • A/C drain hose is a rubber or plastic hose that helps to drain water from your car’s air conditioner • The hose is usually located near the bottom of the A/C unit, and it may be connected to a drain pipe • Over time, the hose can become clogged with dirt and debris, which can cause it to leak or even break

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Ignition coil definition and meaning
item.description: • The ignition coil in a car is responsible for providing the spark that ignites the air/fuel mixture in the engine’s cylinders • It is a vital component of the vehicle’s ignition system, and if it fails, the engine will not start • The coil is typically located near the engine’s spark plugs, and it consists of two coils of wire wound around each other

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Shift lock/starter safety switch definition and meaning
item.description: • Auto shift lock/starter safety switch is a device that is installed in the shifter assembly of a vehicle • It is designed to prevent the engine from starting unless the shifter is in the proper position • This safety feature is important because it can help to prevent accidental or unauthorized starting of the vehicle

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Cabin lighting definition and meaning
item.description: • Cabin lighting is a feature in many modern cars that helps to illuminate the interior of the vehicle • It is usually located near the ceiling or on the dashboard, and it can be controlled by a switch or knob • Cabin lighting can help to make the inside of a car feel more welcoming and comfortable, and it can also be used to provide additional illumination when driving at night

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Active suspension definition and meaning
item.description: • Active suspension is an automotive suspension that actively uses electronic or hydraulic controls to dampen bumps and vibrations • It was first introduced in the 1980s and has become increasingly popular, especially in luxury vehicles • Active suspension can provide a smoother ride than traditional passive suspension

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Activator definition and meaning
item.description: • Activator chemicals are typically sulfur-based compounds, which act as catalysts to promote vulcanization in car tires • Other types of activators, such as zinc oxide, can also be used • The amount of activator used in a rubber compound varies depending on the type of vulcanization process being used and the desired properties of the finished product.

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">CUV definition and meaning
item.description: • A Crossover Utility Vehicle (CUV) is a vehicle built on a unibody construction, which combines features of a passenger car and an SUV • CUVs typically have better fuel economy and handling than SUVs, while offering more interior space and cargo capacity than a sedan • One key difference between a CUV and an SUV is their construction

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Brake bias definition and meaning
item.description: • Brake bias is the distribution of braking force between a vehicle’s front and rear wheels • It is typically expressed as a percentage, with higher numbers indicating more braking force at the front wheels • Brake bias is critical because it affects how a vehicle will respond under braking

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Spark plug definition and meaning
item.description: • A spark plug is an important part of a car’s engine • It helps to ignite the fuel and air mixture in the cylinders, which in turn powers the car • Over time, spark plugs can become fouled or damaged, which can cause engine problems

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Hyundai definition and meaning
item.description: • Hyundai is a South Korean multinational conglomerate headquartered in Seoul • It comprises over 80 subsidiaries and affiliates, with operations throughout the world • The company was founded in 1967 as Hyundai Construction and later renamed Hyundai Motor Group in 1985

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Steering angle sensor definition and meaning
item.description: • The steering angle sensor is a vital component in modern cars and helps to ensure safe driving conditions • It is responsible for measuring the angle of the steering wheel and relaying this information back to the car’s computer system • This allows the car to adjust its speed and braking according to the driver’s inputs, helping to avoid accidents

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Original equipment definition and meaning
item.description: • Most cars on the road today are fitted with what is known as Original Equipment (OE) parts • These are the parts that are installed by the car manufacturer at the factory when the car is built • There are many benefits to using OE parts in your car

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Air pollution score definition and meaning
item.description: • The air pollution score is a measure of the number of pollutants emitted by the car • The higher the score, the cleaner the car • The score is based on emissions tests conducted by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Rim drop definition and meaning
item.description: • Rim drop is a term used to describe the process of lowering the bead of a tire onto the wheel rim • This is typically done by hand, although some people use a machine to help with the process • The goal is to get the bead as close to the edge of the rim as possible, which helps to improve the tire’s grip on the road and prevents it from slipping off the rim during cornering or braking

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Opposite lock definition and meaning
item.description: • When a car is turning, the wheels on the inside of the turn move more slowly than the wheels on the outside • This can cause the car to skid, or slide • To prevent this from happening, drivers use a technique called “opposite lock.” With opposite lock, the driver turns the steering wheel in the opposite direction of the turn

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">Solenoid definition and meaning
item.description: • Solenoids are electromechanical devices that are used to convert electrical energy into mechanical energy • In a car, a solenoid is often used to open and close the valves in the engine • The solenoid is controlled by an electronic control unit (ECU), which sends electrical signals to the solenoid to activate it

item.title: <span style="font-family: sans-serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 18px;">SUV definition and meaning
